content.question:
Human epidermal growth factor (EGF) is a protein that stimulates cell division and growth by binding to its receptor, human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (<math alttext="H E R 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>HER</mi><mn>2</mn></math>). Certain types of cancer are caused when the overexpression of EGF activates a cell-signaling pathway, leading to uncontrolled cell division.
Which of the following best explains how a drug can be used to inhibit tumor growth caused by EGF overexpression?

choices.label: The drug binds to <math alttext="H E R 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>HER</mi><mn>2</mn></math>, preventing the activation of the signaling pathway.
The drug acts as a positive regulator of transcription of the gene encoding EGF.
The drug activates the receptor in the absence of EGF, leading to the activation of the signaling pathway.
The drug enables the cells to progress through the <math alttext="S slash G 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>S/G</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub></math> checkpoint.

content.answer: The drug binds to <math alttext="H E R 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>HER</mi><mn>2</mn></math>, preventing the activation of the signaling pathway.
